Literature Review: Public health surveillance is a crucial component of modern public health practice, and its importance has been highlighted by the COVID-19 pandemic. The ongoing, systematic collection, analysis, and interpretation of health data is essential for identifying and predicting future disease trends. However, the current national notifiable disease reporting system (NNDRS) has limitations, including delays in reporting and incomplete data. In this review, we discuss the advantages and limitations of the current NNDRS, lessons learned from the COVID-19 pandemic, and technological innovations in public health surveillance, including geographic information systems (GIS), spatial modeling, artificial intelligence, information technology, data science, and the digital twin method. We conclude that technology-driven innovative public health surveillance systems are expected to further improve the timeliness, completeness, and accuracy of case reporting during outbreaks and enhance feedback and transparency.
